posts.name: Lucas
posts.cooked: Our battery housings keep unplugging from one another. We tried using a “battery clip” to keep it in place but had no success. Any ideas?
Are the connectors the same color? If yes, did you buy an off brand connector for the batteries or for the robot side?

posts.name: Lucas
posts.cooked: they are the same connector, pretty sure they are the official one

posts.name: Fletch
posts.cooked: When are they unplugging…? When sitting still? In a match under heavy defense with a battery thats not well secured?

posts.name: Mr.R^2
posts.cooked:
If you are using the KOP battery cradle, did you attach the robot side to it as they recommend? It took us years to figure out that is what those holes are for, and now that we use them, it solved this issue for us.

If not, you can also use Velcro or releasable zip ties to keep the two sides together.

posts.name: Andy Mundell
posts.cooked: Keep looking for a better solution, but in the meantime ziptie those connectors together every match.

posts.name: Lucas
posts.cooked: during some intense matches, and the battery is secured

posts.name: Jon Stratis
posts.cooked: A picture of your robot, with a focus on the battery mounting and connectors, would be helpful in identifying any potential causes!

posts.name: Lucas
posts.cooked:
IMG_1111 828×652 66.4 KB This is what we currently have, but it doesn’t work really well

IMG_1111 828×652 66.4 KB

IMG_1111 828×652 66.4 KB

posts.name: Drakxii
posts.cooked: Would recommend replacing battery connector on the robot, the leads and/or spring steel in the SB-50 are likely worn out.

posts.name: Jon Stratis
posts.cooked: Hard to tell in the picture - is one side hard mounted to something immovable?  And do the leads going from there to the battery have any slack in them?  Do you find it tough to pull apart by hand, or easy?

posts.name: Lucas
posts.cooked: it is mounted to something immovable, the leads don’t have any slack, and it is considerably easy to pull apart by hand if you wiggle it a little bit

posts.name: Jon Stratis
posts.cooked:
All of that is, generally speaking, bad.  By not having any slack in the system, if something moves (like a ~13 lb battery jostling with an impact), then that pulls at the connection, causing it to come apart.

Likely your easiest solution is to un-mount the connector and create a little slack in the system.  That will certainly help.  After that, you can look to better secure the connectors together - others have mentioned zip ties, which I know some teams do even if I don’t generally recommend it (I like being able to unplug the battery without needing any tools).  FWIW, my team has never mounted the connector to the robot, and we’ve never had it come apart during a match over the past 17 years.  We’ve also never needed to zip tie it together.  Having some slack in the system generally allows it to absorb any impacts without coming apart, and we use a new connector robot-side every year, and a new one for every new battery.

If those connectors have been used a while, you may also consider replacing them - new ones typically are harder to separate.

posts.name: Lucas
posts.cooked: alright, thank you so much for all the help!
Solidly mounting the connector on the robot side is fine as long as there is slack. Having slack is the key. Helps when you use the really flexible(EPDM) cable too.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: My views are mine and mine alone

posts.custom_user_title: My views are mine and mine alone

posts.name: philso
posts.cooked: If there is insufficient slack in the battery cables, zip tying the two connectors together will transfer the stress to the battery cables. Eventually, one or more of them will break or will be ripped out of the connector housings.

posts.name: Benjamin Broudy
posts.cooked: Before every match no matter what I zip tie all the way around both connectors with a thuck zip tie. Like thru both wires of one around thru both wires of the other one snd finish the loop and close the zip tie. This is just general advice tho seems like you should increase your cable length but i still think everyone should do that. Weve lost comps because we didnt

posts.name: Lucas
posts.cooked: We are going to do this from now on, thanks!
